Unhackable - No Hard to hack - yes. Unlimited budget - Desirable but not necessary An open mind - Absolute necessity. Lets start from that everyone hate security and most of then do not understand security. One must remember, security is not a product (definitely its not a single product). People- Process-Technology makes security. Also, one have to keep user experience in mind when applying security. As a general principle, as security increases, user experience decreases. Till today the actual race is who bring the product to the market first. Or who’s product works faster. In other words, if you want a car to run faster (after all the engineering hard work), you strip down your car to bare metal and get rid of any additional weight to make it run faster (with the same engine). This “additional weight” in information world is security. Also, not to forget that the weakest link in the whole security is the user AND that the governments are forcing companies to add backdoors into their product so that they can spy on a individual/group or a entire nation. These backdoors are then abused by the hackers to hack individual or a company. Most of the Security products are very effective however they have boundaries, they work really well within their own boundaries. For example anti virus do not work very well with encrypted data. So the boundary for Antivirus is that it requires dats in clear for it to make sense. Boundaries for a encryption solution is that when a customer request an encrypted data. He can do anything with it, so you need DLP like solution. However it still do not stop anyone from clicking pictures of your screen using mobile cameras (hence we cannot have 100% security ever. Similarly all other security products have similar sort of boundaries. Anything that is not covered by the technology is covered by process and policies. So, you have to design a policy covering all this. Segregate the network, segregated users at each level, machine, network, application everything. Do the proper pen testing of everything that you put on. Choose new team each time, ask them to treat it as first time audit. Run open hackathon. As I mentioned earlier…. Administrative nightmage and unlimited budget. Most companies are just interested in checking the boxes that saves them from Audits (do not get me started on Auditors). Also, one should start rewarding their security personnel. Anyone who ctreate and better design will with same/ new technology should get something significant. Just want to close with Despite not matter how much you invest in all above recommend, you might be in hacking process right now may be because of a “zero day exploit” that you/anyone don't know about.
